pages.text: $(l:materials/Bismuth)Bismuth$(/l) $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l) or $(l:materials/Bismuth)bismuth$(/l) $(l:materials/Brass)brass$(/l) is a $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) alloy which typically contains 1-3% $(l:materials/Bismuth)bismuth$(/l) by weight, although some alloys contain over 6% Bi. This $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l) alloy is very corrosion-resistant, a property which makes it suitable for use in environments such as the ocean. $(l:materials/Bismuth)Bismuth$(/l) bronzes and brasses are more malleable, thermally conductive, and polish better than regular brasses. The most common industrial application of these metals are as

bearings, however the material has been in use since the late nineteenth century as kitchenware and mirrors. $(l:materials/Bismuth)Bismuth$(/l) $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l) was also found in ceremonial Inca knives at Machu Picchu. Recently, pressure for the substitution of hazardous metals has increased and with it $(l:materials/Bismuth)bismuth$(/l) $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l) is being marketed as a green alternative to leaded $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l) bearings and bushings.
